Award.AwardTitle: EXP: Educating Teens to Understand Personal Health (GET-UP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This team is creating a new kind of video-game, one that incorporates the changing characteristics of the person playing the game into the game play itself. This provides game players (learners) with an alternate perspective on their own capabilities and the effects and impacts of their choices and behaviors. In this case, the game is aimed at children learning about health and nutrition, and learners (adolescents and pre-adolescents) wear a wrist band that captures personal-health data (e.g., heart rate, breathing) and incorporates that data into the capabilities of the game player within the game. Game design and game play are based on literatures on game design (especially for promoting learning), embodied cognition, identity development, and effecting behavior change. Research focuses on how learning, identity, and changes in real-life behavior unfold over time and what it is about the game that is influencing or driving those changes.

The U.S. experiences one of the highest rates of chronic disease in the world, and health during childhood is a critical predictor of disease onset in later adulthood. Technological innovations that can help children understand the effects of their nutrition and behavior choices on health and that provide information at times when children are interested in seeking that information have potential to play a role in promoting good habits. This project is aiming to create a video game that will be engaging enough to stimulate curiosity and understanding of personal health status and of the effects of personal choices on personal health. Ultimately, the goal is to learn more about how to instill healthy habits early in life. While this project is aimed at promoting habits that will lead to good health, what is learned from the investigation will have potential to affect not only public health but also more basic understanding of how habits develop, how to promote habit development, and how to design engaging video games as vehicles for promoting the kind of learning that results in behavior change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A device-and-gaming model using wearable fitness devices, and a narrative online game that converts physical activity into in-game action, hold great potential. In our work, we demonstrated that such a model has the overall ability to hold youth attention and engagement beyond the point where physical activity devices alone lose their novelty and motivational power. That said, the following factors add significant complexity to designing and carrying out such implementations:

Significant efforts can be made toward accessibility and low-entry for low-income populations and schools (designing the game to run in a standard browser window and not requiring separate software or game platforms; making wearable fitness devices available for free to participants); however, we found that schools, communities, and homes across socio-economic strata have dramatically varying levels of the infrastructure and resources required to sync, examine data in dashboards, and play with reliable regularity. Challenges to youth's regular engagement and data preservation/accuracy often stemmed from the surrounding system rather than the pieces of the environment specific to our intervention itself. Furthermore, different communities have different levels of access to spaces for ambulatory or free-form outdoor activity, or safe-travel routes for young pedestrians or bikers, thus constraining youth from low-income communities in their ability to make in-the-moment choices to move more during non-school time. In sum, a goal of our project was to bring a motivating and engaging fitness intervention to a low-income population most at-risk for metabolic disease. While that was somewhat successful, we found that the environmental factors beyond individual motivation and awareness were systemic and very difficult to compensate for. Commercial fitness devices are designed for active middle-class adults with already-existing supportive infrastructures; translating this model for widespread adoption with low-income youth may require the design of entirely different systems and devices. 

The extent to which youth persisted in wearing their devices, trying to achieve or maintain high levels of physical activity, and play Terra out to the conclusion of the campaign was dependent on several factors: 
        (a) whether their typical forms of exercise (running, swimming, martial arts, etc) were compatible with Fitbit or not
        (b) whether they were able to sync passively (using the smartphone app) or had to keep track of and remember to sync using the USB dongle and the school computers
        (c) whether they found some aspect of the game compelling beyond a novelty effect or whether their prefered gaming style (e.g., first-person shooter) was not represented in Terra
        (d) how much youth felt that they had any sense of agency or control over their level of physical activity and the ability to make choices that would increase their activity beyond their baseline

While many youth experienced situations in which there was some perceived inaccuracy in their experience (problems with Fitbit recording, syncing, translation into game metrics, etc), the need to reconcile and problem-solve around why these things were happening proved to be a valuable learning opportunity. Youth were more engaged and reflective about their personal data in instances of dispute than instances of clean data compatibility or alignment with their remembered and embodied experience. Further, the in-game translation proved to be more motivating and engaging in this regard than devices and dashboards alone, because youth were emphatic about whether or not their in-game metrics were "fair" and would devote time and energy to troubleshooting that we did not see during the device-only timeframe of our intervention. 

In conclusion, our project contributes a much-needed perspective to the existing research on games for learning, games for health, fitness devices and engagement, embodied cognition, and personal data literacy. Because our project involved both analyses of "objective" device and game data feeds and also qualitative analyses of youth participants' subjective experiences, we were able to provide explanatory accounts of what would otherwise be opacities in data results (such as apparent disengagement or de-motivation that were actually due to infrastructure challenges or device incompatibility with certain kinds of physical activity). We thus hope that our methods, as well as our results, can serve as a model to others doing research in these areas.
